I'm talking about universities. I actually found university to be a couple of things as a liberal_arts major:

1. Too easy

2. Too expensive

3. Too fraudulent

I distinctly remember asking my liberal_arts professor during my freshman year "is this really something I can make a living out of?" He replied "yes, I do well for myself and I've even had the opportunity to work in many different fields of work including *engineering*[emphasis mine]"

I knew that degrees were more or less a piece of paper to get a higher pay grade so this news was nice to hear. I imagined that I would be able to slide into a job in my field fairly easily if *he* got a job outside of his field. But the thing is, it wasn't that easy. I got my degree without ever lifting a finger. I made the dean[.] list every semester while skipping classes all the time. 

Clearly, I joined a "pay to win" university despite being fairly large and well known. I trusted that this system of education would return to me a profession. But it didn't. I've been taking night classes for two years since I graduated. Now I do low-income software engineering wherever someone will take me. I always have to put my night classes / online classes *above* my full-fledged degree. I could have saved $60,000 and been earning twice as much if I just went to community college for classes in the tech field. 

The public school system is heavily under funded. I also think that schools that get money based on performance are criminal. But that[.] a lot more typing that I don't want to do right now. Maybe I'll edit this later if I get enough replies.
